channel.title: NYT > Climate and Environment
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: Studying Antarctica’s Ice From the Side of a Helicopter
item.description: The fastest way into the gaps between gigantic blocks of a broken-up glacier is by lowering instruments from above, through the door of a helicopter.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: Climate ‘Superfund’ Bills Spread Nationwide, Despite Legal Battles
item.description: The laws aim to force oil companies to help pay for damage from global warming. Industry is gearing up for state-by-state battles.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick
item.media:credit: Charles Krupa/Associated Press
item.media:description: Flooding in Vermont in July 2023. The state was the first to adopt a climate “superfund” law. Other states are now following.

item.title: Trump Administration Is Delaying Hundreds of Wind and Solar Projects
item.description: Federal agencies are delaying approvals for renewable energy projects on both federal land and private property at a time when electricity demand is going up.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer and Rebecca F. Elliott
item.media:credit: Simon Simard for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Trump administration has been halting or delaying federal approvals that were once seen as routine.

item.title: A Chevron Refinery May Take in More Venezuelan Oil. Its Neighbors Are Concerned.
item.description: The American claim on Venezuela’s oil means even more of it could come to a huge Chevron refinery in Mississippi. Neighbors worried about pollution want the company to move them out.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi and Micah Green
item.media:credit: Micah Green for The New York Times

item.title: What’s Behind the Weird Weather That’s Dominated 2026
item.description: While iguanas were stunned by freezing cold in Florida, would-be skiers were looking at dirt on Utah’s slopes. Here’s what’s going on, and when it will finally end.
item.dc:creator: Amy Graff
item.media:credit: Danielle Brahier/Danielle Brahier, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A rare snowfall in Holt, Fla., on Jan. 18.

item.title: What’s Up With This Big Freeze? Some Scientists See Climate Change Link
item.description: A warming Arctic can stretch the polar vortex, a high-altitude air ribbon, one says. The “wobble” can disrupt the jet stream, causing extreme cold in the East.
item.dc:creator: Eric Niiler
item.media:credit: Aristide Economopoulos for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pedestrians walked the snow-covered streets of Jersey City, N.J., during last month’s winter storm. Some scientists say there is a link between a warming planet and the recent frigid temperatures.

item.title: Japan Ocean-Mining Test Successfully Hauls Up Potentially Valuable Mud
item.description: It’s the latest twist in the controversial global race to mine the deep sea for rare-earth elements and other valuable resources.
item.dc:creator: Sachi Kitajima Mulkey
item.media:credit: SIP/Japan Agency for Marine-Earth Science and Technology, via Associated Press

item.title: Trump Opens Marine National Monument in Atlantic to Commercial Fishing
item.description: Off the coast of Cape Cod, the Northeast Canyons and Seamounts Marine National Monument is a unique stretch of ocean that had been protected for a decade.
item.dc:creator: Maxine Joselow
item.category: Northeast Canyons and Seamounts Marine National Monument
Pacific Remote Islands Marine National Monument
item.media:credit: NOAA, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A rare sei whale visiting the waters off New England in 2024.

item.title: A First Look Below Antarctica’s Most Menacing Glacier
item.description: Scientists on the Thwaites Glacier attempted to install equipment beneath the ice to better understand how it is melting. Our climate reporter Raymond Zhong walks us through their landmark experiment and the bittersweet outcome.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong, Chang W. Lee, Christina Thornell, Jon Miller, Stephanie Swart and Shafik Quoraishee

item.title: Contentious Weedkiller Gets a Green Light, in a Blow to the MAHA Agenda
item.description: The chemical, dicamba, is used to control weeds on genetically engineered crops. Courts previously had restricted its use.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:credit: Tom Polansek/Reuters
item.media:description: Dicamba, one of the most widely used herbicides in the United States, is often used on soybeans.

item.title: Rebuilding the Lighthouse of Alexandria, Block by Virtual Block
item.description: An ancient skyscraper considered the seventh wonder of the world crumbled to ruin centuries ago. Now an ambitious archaeological project aims to reassemble it in 3-D.
item.dc:creator: Franz Lidz
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
item.media:credit: Florilegius/Universal Images Group, via Getty Images
item.media:description: A 19th-century engraved depiction of the Pharos of Alexandria.

item.title: Federal Judge Blocks Texas Law Targeting Critics of Fossil Fuels
item.description: The court ruled that it was unconstitutional to bar state agencies from investing with firms that the state had accused of boycotting the oil industry.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick
item.media:credit: Tony Gutierrez/Associated Press
item.media:description: Trucks at an oil field in Midland, Texas. A judge ruled that a 2021 law about investing practices was unconstitutional.

item.title: At a Bonobo’s ‘Tea Party,’ Scientists Find Hints of Imagination
item.description: In a playtime experiment, researchers found that our closest living relatives have the capacity for make-believe, too.
item.dc:creator: Alexa Robles-Gil

item.title: When Venezuelan Oil Comes to the U.S.
item.description: In Mississippi, neighbors of a Chevron plant worry that an influx of Venezuelan oil could increase pollution. They want the company to pay to move them out.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:credit: Micah Green for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Chevron refinery in Pascagoula, Miss.

item.title: He Built a Server to Protect Indigenous Health Data
item.description: Joseph Yracheta was in charge of a repository that compiled and protected tribal health data. Then its funding was cut.
item.dc:creator: Katrina Miller
item.media:credit: Tara Weston for The New York Times

item.title: Babies, Robots and Climate Change
item.description: It’s often assumed that lower birthrates could help slow climate change and A.I. disruption. The reality is more complex.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:credit: Andrea Verdelli for The New York Times

item.title: The Melting Continent
item.description: Today we look at an expedition to Antarctica.
item.dc:creator: Sam Sifton
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: Chevron’s Oil Deals in Venezuela Could Worsen Pollution in Mississippi
item.description: President Trump said he wanted to focus on opening up more Venezuelan oil for U.S. companies. But in Pascagoula, Miss., home to one of Chevron’s largest refineries, some residents worry that this could lead to more pollution. Our climate reporter Hiroko Tabuchi met with some of these residents, who are asking the company to buy their homes.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi, Melanie Bencosme, Christina Shaman, Micah Green and June Kim

item.title: Why U.S. Car Companies Want to Make Giant Batteries
item.description: Even as American automakers have scaled back their ambitions for electric vehicles, some are pivoting to a technology that could help boost renewable energy.
item.dc:creator: Claire Brown
item.media:credit: Sam Hodde/Associated Press
item.media:description: A battery energy storage facility in Saginaw, Texas, in 2023.

item.title: Siemens Energy Bets $1 Billion That A.I. Power Demand Will Last
item.description: The German manufacturer announced plans to expand factories in several U.S. states and build a new plant in Mississippi.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca F. Elliott
item.media:credit: Sean Gallup/Getty Images
item.media:description: A Siemens Energy factory in Berlin in 2017. The company is one of the world’s biggest manufacturers of gas turbines.

item.title: An attempt to study Thwaites Glacier from below meets an icy end.
item.description: Scientists lost their instruments within Antarctica’s most dangerously unstable glacier, though not before getting a glimpse at the warming waters underneath.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Paul Anker, an engineer on the team, checked on the supply of hot water for the drilling operation.

item.title: Attempt to Drill Through Thwaites Glacier Is Foiled
item.description: Scientists lost their instruments within Antarctica’s most dangerously unstable glacier, though not before getting a glimpse at the warming waters underneath.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Threading a cable through the Thwaites glacier in an attempt to place monitoring equipment.

item.title: Judge Hands Trump a Fifth Loss in His Effort to Halt Offshore Wind Projects
item.description: The court ruled that construction can restart on a wind farm off the coast of New York State. The Trump administration had ordered work to stop in December.
item.dc:creator: Maxine Joselow
item.media:credit: Angus Mordant for The New York Times
item.media:description: A staging area for Orsted’s Sunrise Wind project at the Port of Coeymans south of Albany, N.Y., in 2024.

item.title: Snow Drought, Political Shifts and Strikes Batter Ski Industry in Western U.S.
item.description: Little snowpack, strikes by mountain staff and Trump administration policies that are keeping international visitors away have made this a difficult season in the Rockies and beyond.
item.dc:creator: David Goodman
item.media:credit: William Woody for The New York Times
item.media:description: Telluride, in western Colorado, closed for nearly two weeks this winter because of a strike by its ski patrollers. The ski area, shown in a photo from Dec. 27, has also been hurt by a lack of snow.

item.title: Snow Drought in the West Reaches Record Levels
item.description: Warm temperatures and extremely low snowfall threaten water resources for the year.
item.dc:creator: Jim Robbins

item.title: Energy Bills Have Soared Recently. How Can States Bring Costs Down?
item.description: Energy experts said governors and legislatures had tools to keep electricity prices from rising further, and might even be able to lower them.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn and Rebecca F. Elliott
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Electricity rates have soared recently in most states.

item.title: Could the Hudson River Freeze Over?
item.description: New York City is icy and cold right now, but you’re probably not going to be able to walk to New Jersey any time soon.
item.dc:creator: Amy Graff and Joel Eastwood
item.media:credit: José A. Alvarado Jr. for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ice floating in the New York Bay from the East and Hudson Rivers continues to affect ferry operations in Downtown Manhattan.

item.title: D.O.E. Panel to Question Climate Science Was Unlawful, Judge Rules
item.description: The researchers produced a report that was central in a Trump administration effort to stop regulating climate pollution.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Nathan Howard/Reuters
item.media:description: The judge ruled that Energy Secretary Chris Wright violated the law when he handpicked researchers to work in secret to produce a government report on global warming.

item.title: Grids Are Surviving the Storm. But the Next 5 Years Could Be Rough.
item.description: A group that monitors the U.S. electricity system warns that grid reliability is “worsening” and blackout risks are rising for millions of people.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: A crew working to restore power in Austin, Texas, in 2021, after a major storm.

item.title: Drilling Through the Thwaites Glacier for Clues to Its Melting
item.description: A team hopes to place instruments in the waters beneath the colossal Thwaites Glacier, with the help of a drill that uses hot water to punch through ice.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: Algae Growth on Greenland’s Ice Contributes to Melting, Studies Show
item.description: New studies show how algae grows on ice and snow, creating “dark zones” that exacerbate melting in the consequential region.
item.dc:creator: Sachi Kitajima Mulkey

item.title: Tesla’s Model S, Soon to Be History, Changed the Auto Industry
item.description: The company’s chief executive, Elon Musk, said this week that it would stop making the car, an electric pioneer in 2012, as well as the Model X.
item.dc:creator: Neal E. Boudette
item.category: Lexus Division of Toyota Motor Corp
item.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times
item.media:description: “The Model S was a breakthrough and ushered in quite a number of technologies people hadn’t seen before,” said Sam Abuelsamid, an executive at Telemetry, a Detroit communications and research firm.

item.title: Chevron Points to Venezuela’s Promise as Big Oil Earnings Fall
item.description: The two largest U.S. oil companies, Chevron and Exxon Mobil, reported their lowest annual profits in years.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca F. Elliott
item.media:credit: Micah Green for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Chevron refinery in Pascagoula, Miss.

item.title: Winter Storm to Hit Carolinas With Snow, Winds and Freezing Cold
item.description: Southern towns more used to hurricane preparation than snowstorms may experience some of their highest snow totals in years.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina, Emily Cochrane and Judson Jones
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Governors Dive Into an Impasse Over Colorado River Water Use
item.description: State leaders gathered in Washington amid threats of lawsuits over a diminishing water supply. They reported mixed progress.
item.dc:creator: Scott Dance
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: Over the past two decades, heat and changing precipitation patterns have significantly reduced the Colorado River’s flow.

item.title: Climate Change Is Fueling Extremes, Both Hot and Cold
item.description: The possibility of snow in Tampa, Fla. Record heat and fires in Australia. Scientists say climate change is exacerbating weather extremes.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles
item.media:credit: Andres Kudacki for The New York Times
item.media:description: A snowy street in Jersey City, N.J., on Monday.

item.title: Svalbard Polar Bears Are Getting Fatter (for Now), Study Finds
item.description: Seals favored by Svalbard bears are becoming easier to hunt as ice declines, a study found. But researchers say the situation may be temporary.
item.dc:creator: Eric Niiler

item.title: Why a New Mexico Developer Quit Natural Gas
item.description: For John Moscato, a land developer in Las Cruces, N.M., installing gas lines at new home sites was “an ongoing headache.” Ditching gas saved him money.
item.dc:creator: Cara Buckley
item.media:credit: Paul Ratje for The New York Times

item.title: Why Some Cold States Are Making It Cheaper to Run a Heat Pump
item.description: New discounts can make heat pumps go from a bad investment to a good idea.
item.dc:creator: Francesca Paris
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Tesla Profit Slumps, but Investors May Not Care
item.description: The automaker also said it would invest $2 billion in xAI, the artificial intelligence company controlled by its C.E.O., Elon Musk, and stop making the two oldest models in its lineup.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing
item.media:credit: Annie Flanagan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Falling car sales have taken a toll on Tesla’s net profit. The company announced Wednesday that it would stop producing its S and X model cars within months.

item.title: Unions Sue FEMA Over Work Force Cuts They Say Threaten Readiness
item.description: The suit argues that the recent dismissals and plans for further cuts violate laws designed to preserve the disaster response agency’s independence and capabilities.
item.dc:creator: Scott Dance
item.category: American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees
item.media:credit: Al Drago/Getty Images
item.media:description: FEMA’s national response center in Washington last week. About 1,000 agency employees were expected to lose their jobs this month, but the cuts were paused because of winter weather.

item.title: Dutch Court Orders Netherlands to Protect Bonaire From Climate Change
item.description: Bonaire, a Dutch overseas territory, deserves the same protections as Europe, the ruling said. The decision adds to a growing body of precedent worldwide.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Piroschka Van De Wouw/Reuters
item.media:description: Marieke Vellekoop, director of Greenpeace Netherlands, center, with plaintiffs from Bonaire in court in The Hague in October.

item.title: Camping on Antarctica’s Thwaites Glacier
item.description: After working and camping for a week on Thwaites Glacier, scientists were ready to start drilling into the ice, if only the weather would let them.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: Doomsday Clock Ticks Closer Than Ever to Apocalypse
item.description: Wars, climate change, disruptive technologies and the rise of autocracy over the past year prompted scientists to set the clock at 85 seconds to midnight.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:credit: Pablo Martinez Monsivais/Associated Press
item.media:description: The Doomsday Clock of the Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists was displayed during a news conference at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace in Washington on Friday.

item.title: Pillbugs Are Getting Top Dollar Online. Poachers Have Noticed.
item.description: A robust, largely unregulated online trade in isopods could pose a serious threat to some vulnerable species, scientists warn.
item.dc:creator: Madeline Shaw
item.media:credit: Nicky Bay
item.media:description: The Cuban Spiky, Pseudarmadillo spinosus, is one of the isopods most prized by hobbyists. A few live specimens can sell for hundreds of dollars.

item.title: Judge Revives Wind Farm That Trump Halted Off Martha’s Vineyard
item.description: The project, known as Vineyard Wind, was already 95 percent complete when the Trump administration ordered construction to stop.
item.dc:creator: Maxine Joselow
item.media:credit: Randi Baird for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Vineyard wind farm in the Atlantic Ocean off Martha’s Vineyard, Mass.

item.title: A Shift for NOAA’s Surveys: From Science to Mining
item.description: A $20 million agency project will aid companies prospecting the sea for critical minerals.
item.dc:creator: Eric Niiler and Sachi Kitajima Mulkey
item.category: Bureau of Ocean Energy Management, Regulation and Enforcement
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: A ship charted to explore the seabed in the Gulf of Mexico in 2021.

item.title: Michigan Sues Oil Giants, Saying They Collude to Make Energy Costlier
item.description: The lawsuit accuses the companies of raising prices by working against solar and wind power and by downplaying the risks of climate change.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick
item.media:credit: Brandon Bell/Getty Images
item.media:description: ExxonMobil is among several major companies and groups named in the Michigan lawsuit.

item.title: Radar Scans of Antarctica Offer Clues to What’s Happening on Jupiter’s Moon
item.description: Scientists are using radar to study damaged ice both in Antarctica and, with the help of a NASA spacecraft, on Jupiter’s ocean moon of Europa.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: An engineer aboard the icebreaker Araon prepared a helicopter with ice-penetrating radar for a flight over the Thwaites Glacier.

item.title: Microsoft Pledged to Save Water. In the A.I. Era, It Expects Water Use to Soar.
item.description: Driven by the artificial intelligence frenzy, Microsoft is internally projecting that water use at its data centers will more than double by 2030 from 2020, including in places that face shortages.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano, Paul Mozur and Karen Weise

item.title: U.S Has Officially Withdrawn From the Paris Climate Accord
item.description: The United States is the only country to pull out of the global agreement among nations to fight climate change. European diplomats say the U.S. reputation is suffering.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Paul Ratje for The New York Times
item.media:description: Moves by the Trump administration underline America’s isolation in the effort to control the greenhouse gases, mostly from the burning of fossil fuels, that are dangerously heating the planet.

item.title: G.M. Shares Rise as Investors Are Encouraged by 2026 Prospects
item.description: The automaker said that it would buy back stock worth up to $6 billion and that it expected profit to rise this year after it pulled back from electric vehicle production.
item.dc:creator: Neal E. Boudette
item.media:credit: Brett Carlsen for The New York Times
item.media:description: A General Motors factory in Spring Hill, Tenn. G.M. said on Tuesday it planned to introduce a more advanced version of its Super Cruise driver assistance system in 2028.
